description: From Middle English ravyschen, from Anglo-Norman, from Old French ravis-, present participle stem of ravir (“to seize; to take away hastily”), from Vulgar Latin *rapire, from Latin rapere. See also rape.

verbs.description: ravish (third-person singular simple present ravishes, present participle ravishing, simple past and past participle ravished)

entries.meaning: (obsolete or archaic) To seize and carry away by violence; to snatch by force.
(transitive, usually passive) To transport with joy or delight; to delight to ecstasy.
(slang) To have vigorous sexual intercourse with.
